case_name: R.M.D.C. Chamarbaugwala v. State of Mysore

facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 517 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 517 of 1960. Appeal from the Judgment and order dated November 20,

facts.text: Appeal from the Judgment and order dated November 20, 1958, of the Mysore High Court in Civil Writ Petition No. 234 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and order dated November 20, 1958, of the Mysore High Court in Civil Writ Petition No. 234 of 1957. Porus A. Mehta, J. R. Gagrat and Gopalakrishnan, for the appellants.

facts.text: Mysore High Court dismissed the petition of the appellants made under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal against the judgment and order of the High Court of Mysore dismissing the petition of the appellants made under Art. 226 of the Constitution. The appellants.

facts.text: Appellants were conducting prize competitions since the month of August 1948 in the State of Mysore with the permission of the Government of the erstwhile State of Mysore.

anchor.surface_text: were companyducting since the month of August 1948, what were called prize companypetitions in the State of Mysore with the permission of the Government of the erstwhile State of Mysore. An Act called the Mysore Lotteries and Prize Competitions Control and Tax Act, 1951  Act 27 of 1951 , hereinafter called the Mysore Act was passed by the Mysore Legislature and came into force as from June 21, 1951.

facts.text: Mysore Lotteries and Prize Competitions Control and Tax Act, 1951 (Act 27 of 1951) came into force on June 21, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: An Act called the Mysore Lotteries and Prize Competitions Control and Tax Act, 1951  Act 27 of 1951 , hereinafter called the Mysore Act was passed by the Mysore Legislature and came into force as from June 21, 1951. The Rules made thereunder came, into force on February 1, 1952.

facts.text: Rules under Mysore Act came into force on February 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The Rules made thereunder came, into force on February 1, 1952. Previous to that the Bombay Legislature had passed a similar Act called the Bombay Lotteries and Prize Competitions Control and Tax Act, 1948, which was amended in November 1952.

facts.text: Bombay Lotteries and Prize Competitions Control and Tax Act, 1948 amended by Bombay Act 30 of 1952 in November 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Previous to that the Bombay Legislature had passed a similar Act called the Bombay Lotteries and Prize Competitions Control and Tax Act, 1948, which was amended in November 1952. by the Bombay Act 30 of 1952. In December 1952 and January 1953 petitions under Art. 226 were filed in the High Court of Bombay challenging the Bombay Act.

facts.text: Bombay High Court held on January 12, 1955 that provisions of Bombay Amendment Act unconstitutional and taxes hit by Art. 301.

anchor.surface_text: On January 12, 1955 the Bombay High Court held that the provisions of the Bombay Amendment Act above referred to were unconstitutional and that the taxes imposed under the provisions of that Act were hit by Art. 301 of the Constitution.

facts.text: States of Andhra, Bombay, Madras, U.P., Hyderabad, Madhya Bharat, Pepsu and Saurashtra passed resolutions under Art. 252(1) authorizing Parliament to legislate on prize competitions.

anchor.surface_text: It was for that reason that the States of Andhra, Bombay, Madras U. P., Hyderabad, Madhya, Bharat, Pepsu and Saurashtra passed resolutions under Art. 252 1  of the Constitution authorising Parliament to legislate for the companytrol and regulation of prize companypetition and in pursuance thereof Parliament passed the Prize Competitions Act  Act 42 of 1955

facts.text: Parliament passed Prize Competitions Act (Act 42 of 1955), received assent October 22, 1955, came into force April 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: hereinafter called the Central Act which Received the assent of the President on October 22, 1955, and came into force on April 1, 1956. On February 24, 1956, the Mysore Legislature passed a, resolution adopting the said Act.

facts.text: Mysore Legislature passed resolution adopting Central Act on February 24, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On February 24, 1956, the Mysore Legislature passed a, resolution adopting the said Act. The resolutions passed by the various States and the resolution passed by the Mysore Legislature will be quoted in a later part of this judgment.

facts.text: Appellants filed petition under Art. 32 in Supreme Court on April 7, 1956 challenging Central Act, dismissed reported as R.M.D.C. Chamarbaugwala v. Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: On April 7, 1956, the appellants filed a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution in the Supreme Court challenging the validity of the Central Act but that petition was dismissed and is reported as R.M.D.C. Chamarbaugwala v. The Union of India  1 .

facts.text: Stay of operation of Central Act granted to appellants on April 16, 1956 pending disposal of Art. 32 petition.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of their petition under Art. 32 the appellants applied for and wore granted a stay of the operation of the Central Act pending the disposal of the said writ petition. This was on April 16, 1956.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment in Art. 32 petition on April 9, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the Supreme Court in that petition was given. on April 9, 1957. On August 31, 1957, the  1  1957 S.C.R. 930, 939.  2  1957 S.C.R. 874, 929.

facts.text: Mysore Lotteries Prize Competitions Control and Tax Amendment Ordinance, 1957 (Ord. 6 of 1957) issued on August 31, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: On August 31, 1957, the  1  1957 S.C.R. 930, 939.  2  1957 S.C.R. 874, 929. Mysore Lotteries Prize Competitions Control and Tax  Amendment  Ordinance, 1957  Ord. 6 of 1957  was issued by the Governor of Mysore

facts.text: Ordinance enacted into Mysore Act 26 of 1957 on September 28, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: and thus for the period of about 16 months the appellants carried on prize companypetitions as before. The Ordinance was enacted into an Act on September 28, 1957, which is Mysore Act 26 of 1957.

facts.text: Appellants carried on prize competitions between March 31, 1956 and August 31, 1957 due to stay.

anchor.surface_text: By adding a proviso to s.15 of the Mysore Act all prize companypetitions companyducted between March 31,1956, and August 31 1957, were brought within the purview of the amended Act. Thus the prize companypetitions which as a result of the stay of the operation of the Central Act were companyducted by the appellants

facts.text: Appellants called upon to file returns on September 10, 1957, granted 15 days extension, filed under protest.

anchor.surface_text: became subject to the operation of the Mysore Act as amended. The appellants on September 10, 1957, were called upon to file their returns but at their request for extension of time, they were given another 15 days in which to file their return. They filed their return but under protest.

facts.text: Gross collections by appellants Rs. 26,47,147-5-9, provisional tax demanded Rs. 3,30,893-7-0.

anchor.surface_text: The gross companylections were of a sum of Rs. 26,47,147-5-9 and on that the appellants were called open to pay up provisionally a sum of Rs. 3,30,893- 7-0. As the money was number paid within the time specified proceedings were taken under s. 6  1  of the Revenue Recovery Act, 1890  Central Act 1 of 1890 ,

facts.text: Proceedings under Revenue Recovery Act 1890 taken, properties attached and one sold, proceeds deposited.

anchor.surface_text: As the money was number paid within the time specified proceedings were taken under s. 6  1  of the Revenue Recovery Act, 1890  Central Act 1 of 1890 , and certain properties moveable and immoveable were attached and one of the properties was sold and the price so realised was deposited in the Government treasury.

facts.text: Mysore High Court writ petition under Art. 226 challenging Mysore amending Act dismissed on November 20, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The Mysore amending Act was challenged in the High Court of Mysore by a petition under Art, 226 which was dismissed on November 20, 1958 and against that judgment and order this appeal has been brought pursuant to a certificate of the, High Court under Art. 132  1  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appeal brought pursuant to certificate under Art. 132 confined to interpretation of Art. 252.

anchor.surface_text: and against that judgment and order this appeal has been brought pursuant to a certificate of the, High Court under Art. 132  1  of the Constitution. The Certificate was companyfined to the interpretation of Art. 252 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Mysore Legislative Assembly passed resolution on February 23, 1956 adopting Central Act.

anchor.surface_text: Resolution passed by the Mysore Legislative Assembly on 23rd, February, 1956. Whereas for the purpose of securing uniformity in legislation it is desirable that the companytrol and regulation of Prize Compe- titions and all other matters ancillary thereto should be regulated in the State of Mysore by the Prize Competitions Act, 1955  Central Act 42 of 1955  passed by Parliament

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner called upon appellants to produce accounts on September 10, 1957 for competitions from April 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On September 10, 1957, the Deputy Commissioner, Bangalore, called upon the appellants to produce accounts in respect of prize companypetitions companyducted as from April 1, 1956, up to the date of the closure of the companypetitions and three days were given to companyply with that numberice.

facts.text: Appellants submitted statements on October 9, 1957 showing gross collection Rs. 26,47,147-5-9.

anchor.surface_text: These statements were submitted on October 9, 1957, and at the end of the statements which showed a gross companylection of Rs. 26,47,147- 5-9, there was the following endorsement -

issues.text: Do the resolutions surrender the whole subject of prize competitions to Parliament including power to tax

holdings.text: Resolutions under Article 252(1) did not surrender the states' power to tax prize competitions under Entry 62 List II, as they only covered control and regulation under Entry 34.

anchor.surface_text: The pivot of the appellants argument is that the words control and regulation and ,incidental and ancillary thereto included power of taxation but this argument is not well founded. The power in regard to betting and gambling is contained in entry 34 of the State List which as follows . Entry 34 Betting and gambling.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entries 34 (control) and 62 (taxation) are separate legislative heads; resolutions limited to control/regulation; distribution of powers per Constitution lists; foreign precedents inapplicable.

holdings.text: Amended Mysore Act does not violate Article 252(2) as tax is not a method of control or indirect amendment of Central Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Tax under separate entry 62, not control; no surrender of tax power; Central Act silent on tax does not prohibit state tax.

holdings.text: Mysore Legislature could amend its own Act even if partially inconsistent with Central Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Doctrine of eclipse: state law not repealed but eclipsed by central law; amendment removes repugnant parts, reviving valid portions.

holdings.text: Amended s.12(1)(b) of Mysore Act not repugnant to Central Act after omission of licensing words; only repugnant portion void under Art.254(1).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendment retrospectively omits repugnant licensing reference; taxation portion independent and valid; cites Deep Chand.

holdings.text: Tax under Mysore Act not colourable legislation; validity depends on legislative competence, not motive.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Competence under entry 62; motives irrelevant; cites K.C. Gajapati Narayan Deo and Gwyer CJ.

holdings.text: Assessment based on appellants' return is final, not provisional.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Return accepted as basis for demand; High Court finding upheld.

holdings.text: No fresh notification required after amendment; notification valid as amended s.12(1)(b) constitutional.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification concerns rate, not licensing; tied to valid amended provision.

holdings.text: Recovery proceedings valid; tax demand complied with notice terms as no payment or challan produced within week.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of compliance; demand notice terms met for recovery.

holdings.text: Prize competitions fall under betting/gambling (entry 34); tax thereon under entry 62; Mysore Act within competence.

anchor.surface_text: Thus the Central Act is with respect to betting and gambling under entry 34 of List II and the taxing sections of the Mysore Act are with respect to a tax on betting and gambling under entry 62.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies prior ruling in State of Bombay v. R.M.D. Chamarbaugwala; territorial nexus exists.

Chamarbaugwala  2  . During the pendency of their petition under Art. 32 the appellants applied for and wore granted a stay of the operation of the Central Act pending the disposal of the said writ petition.

During the pendency of their petition under Art. 32 the appellants applied for and wore granted a stay of the operation of the Central Act pending the disposal of the said writ petition. This was on April 16, 1956. The judgment of the Supreme Court in that petition was given. on April 9, 1957.

precedents.citation: re The Central Provinces and Berar Act No. XIV of 1938  3

anchor.surface_text: re The Central Provinces and Berar Act No. XIV of 1938  3  by Sulaiman, J. Thus the subject of betting and gambling given in entry 34 of List II and the taxes on betting and gambling as given in entry 62 of List II have to be read separately as separate powers and therefore when companytrol and regulation of prize companypetitions was surrendered to Parliament by the resolutions above quoted the power to tax under entry 62 of List II which is a separate head, cannot be said to have been surrendered.
